title: National Garden - Set the Peacocks Free
text: We planned to walk through the park solely as a means to get from one point to the next, and were surprisedly pleased with the combination of well manicured paths and wildlife. The one negative has to do with the zoo, which admittedly speaks to a bit of a personal bias. The goats were in a pretty small enclosure, and even worse the peacocks were kept in a small space. In Madrid, the peacocks are free to roam around Parque de El Retiro, though they stayed in the spot that best met their needs. We would have preferred that they were offered the same freedom as the ducks, who have free access to the National Garden but stay around the pond.

title: Top rated Acropolis Museum
text: Unlike larger, overwhelming museums where you end up exhausted and feeling that you somehow missed some good stuff, the Acropolis museum is manageable, fascinating, and well located in the shadows of the actual Acropolis. Take the 15 minutes to watch the film on the top floor, and definitely check out the excavation site beneath. Warning: Your admission ticket lets you into both the museum and excavation site separately, but can be used only once for each. So don’t enter the museum if you really want to see the excavation first (like we did).

title: Best view of Athens, Mount Lycabettus
text: Despite having made peace with missing Mount Lycabettus this trip, we found ourselves walking around it’s base on the way back from lunch in Exarcheia and thought, why not?! We took the funicular slowly up through a dark tunnel and stepped out essentially into a cafe. Spectacular 360 view, good cafe options both food and drink, and even a feisty cat. Easy trip, needs no more than 90 minutes, but definitely stay longer to take in the view from the cafe. Glad not to have missed it!

title: Avocado, nice vegetarian spot in Athens
text: Usually I do not over-order, and I gravitate towards appetizers. So I was surprised when the waitress warned me that the falafel appetizer plus the avocado burger might be too much. And, when the burger arrived, I understood. Way bigger than my mouth, but I would not be defeated. I loved that it is all vegetarian and has a mission of peace and love. And the ambience, especially the upstairs seating on low cushions, was relaxing. Definitely worth a try, we enjoyed it.

title: Safety in numbers - Istiklal Street
text: Immediately after arriving in Istanbul, we encountered a young shoe shiner who “dropped” his brush as he walked past us. We, of course, pointed this out to him and he, in return, thanked us profusely and insisted on giving a “free” shoeshine (for my worn out hiking shoes). We said thank but no thanks and had to essentially run away from him to get him to leave us alone, after which we continued along in the dark through strange and unknown streets to our AirBnB. A bit shaken already, we looked up “scams in Istanbul” and suddenly felt very unsafe. From pickpockets to excessive drink ordering schemes to some very scary and aggressive assaults, Istanbul seemed like an unfriendly place. The next day, with the morning sun providing some hope, we ventured out and soon came upon Istiklal Street. While our guard remained up, the sight of fellow tourists on a wide street with a trolley car calmed our nerves, and allowed us to enjoy the rest of our stay. Istanbul, you are alright in our book!

title: Tahin Karaköy, simple and yummy
text: This relatively simple restaurant in the vibrant neighborhood of Karaköy checked the boxes. Good food, quick service, and simple atmosphere. It was not overly “special” in terms of being a unique Turkish experience, hence only 4 out of 5. That said, my wife and I ate very well for under $15USD total. Enjoy!

title: Neat, but underwhelming
text: It has its moments, but felt more utilitarian than beautiful. The exterior was more impressive than the interior. The floor was carpeted with red carpet, so shoes are forbidden. And columns are not all stone, many seem dry walled. Certainly more of a working mosque than a tourist attraction. That said, it’s right near other must see spots, so should be experienced.

title: Perfect Turkish breakfast
text: As vegetarians who struggle a bit with gluten, we had some anxiety about meals in Istanbul. After reading reviews, we chose Arada Cafe. We had to wait around 30 minutes for our table to be ready (did not make a reservation, not sure if they take them). Definitely worth the wait. They require that patrons order the standard breakfast, with the option of adding items. It included all the must haves, with delicious bread (yes, we had gluten, and it was worth it!) The only add on we purchased was Turkish coffee, as endless tea refills were included. In all, we paid $24USD for a lovely meal with great ambience. Highly recommended!

title: Ancient Agora, unexpected highlight
text: We expected this to be a simple walkthrough, like some of the other sites. But our experience began with a hearty welcome by a cat, followed by a simple but worthwhile museum. And, the Temple of Hephaestus atop a hill is accessible and in fairly good repair.

title: Amazing Acropolis, a unique experience
text: It is hard to believe that something with so much history is still around to be seen up close. Breathtaking. Combined with the panoramic vista, this is unmissable. Beware the rocks, though. Somehow very slippery. And the folks trying to give “free roses” and Hakuna Matata happiness scams (or something).

title: Random Find in Narrowsburgh
text: On a seldom traveled road behind the Main Street in Narrowsburgh, we happened upon this perfect riverside restaurant. Eclectic menu (saag paneer pizza?!), full bar, lots of outdoor seating, and plenty of character. Either for dinner, snack, or a drink, definitely check it out.

title: Old Quebec stroll
text: While the old town area is not that big, it is packed with cute shops and little cafes. Great place to spend a few hours, sitting in the tiny park, perhaps even enjoying a street performer.

title: Walkway underwhelming
text: After Google Maps decided to take me on a creative detour, we embarked over the walkway. Granted it was a very hot day, but the bridge seemed to be more of a sidewalk than the quaint, breathtaking experience we expected. We walked halfway over, took a peek up and down the river, and turned around.
place: Walkway Over the Hudson State Historic Park

title: Delicious, our #1 take-out option
text: We stayed in Barcelona for one week and had take-out from Bembi three times. We are vegetarians who seem to gravitate towards Indian food as our go-to cuisine when traveling. While I cannot speak the experience of dining in, I can say that the reception I received was first class, they spoke fluent English (helpful for a non Spanish speaking tourist), had a comfortable space for me to wait for food to be prepared, and above all make delicious food. The second time I visited in three days the owner/staff greeted me by name (ok, so she tried to but got the name wrong), and treated me like I was a long time friend of the restaurant. I felt welcomed, and appreciated the warmth. Highly recommended!

title: Luxury, welcome oasis from chaos!
text: As an American in India, it took some getting used to the constant movement. Even as I discerned patterns in the chaos over the period of a week, it remained exhausting. The Leela Palace was the calm in the eye of the storm that allowed me and my wife to regroup in quiet, pampered relaxation. All amenities are perfect, from the afternoon tea in the beautiful lounge to the half dozen restaurants to the exceptional breakfast looking out upon the inspiring garden. The staff is helpful and polite. It is not within walking distance of most things (Delhi is really not a walking city), but there are auto-rickshaws waiting across the street, Uber drivers get there in minutes, and cabs are plenty. Spend the extra money on this, it will greatly improve your experience in Delhi.

title: It's what you would expect, and worth it
text: Yes, it is a very large Buddha sitting in a square. What did you expect. Surrounded by some structures, with a shop and restroom near. Take some pictures, soak it in, and move on. You will probably not spend more than 10-15 minutes there.

title: Trying to see Mt Fuji?
text: We were on a mission. Rented bikes and rode for 25 minutes up the coast. And lo and behold, we actually DID see the great mountain. It is imposing and amazing. But since it is still far away and the air was hazy, our cameras did not quite capture it. But we know it is possible, we have seen other photos. Along the beach were children, families, and dogs playing. Not the loveliest sand in the world, but with the beautiful backdrop it certainly suffices.

title: Hit the spot - works for vegetarians
text: Vegetarians tire of sorting through meat focused Japanese restaurants, we stumbled upon Fiore, serving pizza and pasta. Had a crispy crust individual pizza with tomatoes, my wife had the pasta. Fast service, tasty food. A nice, quiet break from the busy temple hopping day.

title: Such cool stuff
text: The street is busy, and the shops offer a cool variety of unnecessary but really neat stuff. We spent 3,000 yen on three wall hangings. Now we just need frames! Also, there was a stand where this guy punches a hole in a grapefruit, juices the inside, and gives you a straw to walk around and suck out the delicious juice. If only there was a garbage can to be found...

title: Meiji Jingu stroll
text: After spending a few days in Nara and Kyoto, I opted to spend the last couple days in bustling Tokyo. But...one more shrine couldn't hurt, right? Well, glad I made the effort. The walk to the center of the park on wide but peaceful paths gave some time to clear the mind. And the shrine itself, with its surrounding gates, was imposing and certainly qualified as a worthwhile stop. Now, it should not be the only shrine you see in Japan, but if you find yourself with an hour or so, go for it!

title: Bright lights of Shibuya
text: I really do not like shopping. But...my wife does. And, as a New York City dweller who steers clear of Times Square, I admit I was curious. So I went and, much to my surprise, enjoyed the atmosphere. Yes, lots of people and lights everywhere, but the shops were clean, the energy was positive, and the selections were great. The boutique malls have really good food courts too! Worth the experience, although I'm sure denizens of Tokyo avoid it like the plague.

title: Harajuku experience
text: I only heard about it the day before when made aware of a Gwen Stefani song about the Harajuku girls. They are their own fashion trend, with almost doll like, playful clothing. Well, I did not see many girls running down the block fitting that description in my 30 minute walk down the block, but I did find many adorable shops selling clothing and candy. I almost bought a back back that I'm sure would have looked ridiculous on me. But I guess that's the peer pressure of the block. If anywhere near there, make sure to walk that path. It's kinda fun.

title: Lodi Gardens - amazing photo ops
text: I felt like I was on an Indiana Jones set! The gardens were well cared for, and there was not a great deal of foot traffic on the day we visited. The entire gardens can be seen in an hour or so, depending on how much you choose to stop and take pictures.

title: Gothic quarter stroll
text: The gothic quarter is a great place to find things, from restaurants to clothing stores (a Zara on every corner), tourist trinkets, or fresh squeezed orange juice. Also some wonderful churches. There is a vibrance and energy.

title: Park Guell - be warned
text: The park is amazing, well worth the trip. The warning is related to planning ahead. They only let a certain number of people in at at time to minimize the crowd, so when you buy a ticket it is for a specific entry time, like 11:00. Perhaps it was the time of year we visited (late December), but trying to buy a ticket early enough to enjoy the light (sunset around 17:00) was impossible at the onsite ticket office. Go online and buy a ticket in advance. Then you can just show up and enjoy!!

title: Racing through Las Ramblas
text: So, it really depends on what you are looking for. As a NYC resident who avoids Timed Square at all cost, I am sensitive to equivalent areas in other cities. Las Ramblas is Barcelona's Times Square. Oriented to tourists, with many trinket shops and touristy restaurants. Felt on edge a bit. Conspicuous. Of course, if you enjoy that energy and pace, have at it!!

title: La Pedrera day and night
text: So cool we had to do it twice! Although it seemed expensive, we opted for the day/night package. Includes a daytime tour of the grounds, attic, quarters, and lobby. About 45 minutes or so. Pretty funky structure. At night, after dark, the second part of the experience also includes a tour, literally topped off by a light show on the roof. Lasers play off the sculptures on the roof deck, telling a story. Initially it is pretty neat, but it runs a little long. Overall, an experience I will long remember.

title: India Gate, cool but...
text: I went there to say I was there, but the experience itself left much to be desired. Granted it was over 90 degrees, but the walk around the gigantic stone arched, closely tracked by young men asking to take pictures of us and young women trying to sell is bracelets, is not an experience I plan to duplicate.

title: Cathedral, end of a long walk
text: Although we only walked the last week of the Camino, it was sufficiently exhausting and enriching. The cathedral is the end destination for most, and it lives up to the hype. Make sure to see the swinging smoking incense holder (Botafumeiro), as the visit is not complete without it. It only happens at certain times (unless you or your group pay for a special show).

title: Jabarkhet Wildlife walk
text: Really nice walk. It was not too strenuous, despite some inclined to ascend. The rhododendron were beautiful. We wished we could have seen the Himalayas, but there was too much fog. The highlights were the lone oak and the flag hill.

title: Great food at Doma's
text: They tell you from the start that the food takes a while. It is worth the wait. The veggie shabalay was my favorite, but there were so many amazing options. Seating is limited, but with lots of character. Low tables and seats in some areas, and a second floor with couches. The restaurant is in Landour overlooking the valley. We stayed at the inn, which was equally wonderful.

title: Taj Mahal from Delhi
text: Raja was amazingly informative. He quizzed us, and it was a fun game to try to guess the motivation behind aspects of the design of the Taj Mahal. Raja was dependable, funny, and kind. We felt safe and protected throughout the tour. And he takes great pictures. Additionally, his driver Mukesh, who picked us up from Delhi in the morning, took great care of us. The tour could not have been better organized and thought out. Very highly recommend.

title: Luxury in Delhi
text: Two peaceful, luxurious days in at the ITC Maurya. With so much to see in Delhi, we had limited time in the hotel. That said, the staff was exceptionally accommodating, welcoming, and polite. They made us feel important and cared for, but did not hover around or make us uncomfortable in any way. The breakfast was fresh and perfect, with countless delicious options. The room was comfortable, and high tech ( an iPad to control lighting, tv, etc.) Highly recommended, could have stayed much longer!
place: ITC Maurya, a Luxury Collection Hotel, New Delhi

title: Taj Mahal, a true Wonder
text: It is hard to say anything about the Taj Mahal that has not been said. It lives up to the hype. Towering, majestic, and so detailed. I suggest finding a guide, as there is so much history that we would have missed had we walked through on our own. I also suggest being ready for a massive human traffic jam when you enter the Taj Mahal mausoleum. And watch your pockets there! A must see if you are anywhere near Agra!!

title: Unexpected Dali works
text: We never knew how diverse Dali was. We thought of him as mostly melting clocks, deserts, and tigers. But is work is diverse, and there were rooms after rooms of amazing pieces of art. The only negative was the crazy line to get in. Expect to wait at least a hour. The line is intimidating, but it does move.
